1.verse: King David then said to the whole assembly: "My son Solomon, whom alone God has chosen, is still young and immature; the work, however, is great, for this castle is not intended for man, but for the LORD God.

2.verse: For this reason I have stored up for the house of my God, as far as I was able, gold for what will be made of gold, silver for what will be made of silver, bronze for what will be made of bronze, iron for what will be made of iron, wood for what will be made of wood, onyx stones and settings for them, carnelian and mosaic stones, every other kind of precious stone, and great quantities of marble.

3.verse: But now, because of the delight I take in the house of my God, in addition to all that I stored up for the holy house, I give to the house of my God my personal fortune in gold and silver:

4.verse: three thousand talents of Ophir gold, and seven thousand talents of refined silver, for overlaying the walls of the rooms,

5.verse: for the various utensils to be made of gold and silver, and for every work that is to be done by artisans. Now, who else is willing to contribute generously this day to the LORD?"

6.verse: Then the heads of the families, the leaders of the tribes of Israel, the commanders of thousands and of hundreds, and the overseers of the king's affairs came forward willingly

7.verse: and contributed for the service of the house of God five thousand talents and ten thousand darics of gold, ten thousand talents of silver, eighteen thousand talents of bronze, and one hundred thousand talents of iron.

8.verse: Those who had precious stones gave them into the keeping of Jehiel the Gershonite for the treasury of the house of the LORD.

9.verse: The people rejoiced over these free-will offerings, which had been contributed to the LORD wholeheartedly. King David also rejoiced greatly.

10.verse: Then David blessed the LORD in the presence of the whole assembly, praying in these words: "Blessed may you be, O LORD, God of Israel our father, from eternity to eternity.

11.verse: "Yours, O LORD, are grandeur and power, majesty, splendor, and glory. For all in heaven and on earth is yours; yours, O LORD, is the sovereignty; you are exalted as head over all.

12.verse: "Riches and honor are from you, and you have dominion over all. In your hand are power and might; it is yours to give grandeur and strength to all.

13.verse: Therefore, our God, we give you thanks and we praise the majesty of your name."

14.verse: "But who am I, and who are my people, that we should have the means to contribute so freely? For everything is from you, and we only give you what we have received from you.

15.verse: For we stand before you as aliens: we are only your guests, like all our fathers. Our life on earth is like a shadow that does not abide.

16.verse: O LORD our God, all this wealth that we have brought together to build you a house in honor of your holy name comes from you and is entirely yours.

17.verse: I know, O my God, that you put hearts to the test and that you take pleasure in uprightness. With a sincere heart I have willingly given all these things, and now with joy I have seen your people here present also giving to you generously.

18.verse: O LORD, God of our fathers Abraham, Isaac, and Israel, keep such thoughts in the hearts and minds of your people forever, and direct their hearts toward you.

19.verse: Give to my son Solomon a wholehearted desire to keep your commandments, precepts, and statutes, that he may carry out all these plans and build the castle for which I have made preparation."

20.verse: Then David besought the whole assembly, "Now bless the LORD your God!" And the whole assembly blessed the LORD, the God of their fathers, bowing down and prostrating themselves before the LORD and before the king.

21.verse: On the following day they offered sacrifices and holocausts to the LORD, a thousand bulls, a thousand rams, and a thousand lambs, together with their libations and many other sacrifices for all Israel;

22.verse: and on that day they ate and drank in the LORD'S presence with great rejoicing. Then for a second time they proclaimed David's son Solomon king, and they anointed him as the LORD'S prince, and Zadok as priest.

23.verse: Thereafter Solomon sat on the throne of the LORD as king in place of his father David; he prospered, and all Israel obeyed him.

24.verse: All the leaders and warriors, and also all the other sons of King David, swore allegiance to King Solomon.

25.verse: And the LORD exalted Solomon greatly in the eyes of all Israel, giving him a glorious reign such as had not been enjoyed by any king over Israel before him.

26.verse: Thus David, the son of Jesse, had reigned over all Israel.

27.verse: The time that he reigned over Israel was forty years: in Hebron he reigned seven years, and in Jerusalem thirty-three.

28.verse: He died at a ripe old age, rich in years and wealth and glory, and his son Solomon succeeded him as king.

29.verse: Now the deeds of King David, first and last, can be found written in the history of Samuel the seer, the history of Nathan the prophet, and the history of Gad the seer,

30.verse: together with the particulars of his reign and valor, and of the events that affected him and all Israel and all the kingdoms of the surrounding lands.

1.verse: A satan rose up against Israel, and he enticed David into taking a census of Israel.

2.verse: David therefore said to Joab and to the other generals of the army, "Go, find out the number of the Israelites from Beer-sheba to Dan, and report back to me that I may know their number."

3.verse: But Joab replied: "May the LORD increase his people a hundredfold! My lord king, are not all of them my lord's subjects? Why does my lord seek to do this thing? Why will he bring guilt upon Israel?"

4.verse: However, the king's command prevailed over Joab, who departed and traversed all of Israel, and then returned to Jerusalem.

5.verse: Joab reported the result of the census to David: of men capable of wielding a sword, there were in all Israel one million one hundred thousand, and in Judah four hundred and seventy thousand.

6.verse: Levi and Benjamin, however, he did not include in the census, for the king's command was repugnant to Joab.

7.verse: This command displeased God, who began to punish Israel.

8.verse: Then David said to God, "I have sinned greatly in doing this thing. Take away your servant's guilt, for I have acted very foolishly."

9.verse: Then the LORD spoke to Gad, David's seer, in these words:

10.verse: "Go, tell David: Thus says the LORD: I offer you three alternatives; choose one of them, and I will inflict it on you."

11.verse: Accordingly, Gad went to David and said to him; "Thus says the LORD: Decide now -

12.verse: will it be three years of famine; or three months of fleeing your enemies, with the sword of your foes ever at your back; or three days of the LORD'S own sword, a pestilence in the land, with the LORD'S destroying angel in every part of Israel? Therefore choose: What answer am I to give him who sent me?"

13.verse: Then David said to Gad: "I am in dire straits. But I prefer to fall into the hand of the LORD, whose mercy is very great, than into the hands of men."

14.verse: Therefore the LORD sent pestilence upon Israel, and seventy thousand men of Israel died.

15.verse: God also sent an angel to destroy Jerusalem; but as he was on the point of destroying it, the LORD saw and decided against the calamity, and said to the destroying angel, "Enough now! Stay your hand!"The angel of the LORD was then standing by the threshing floor of Ornan the Jebusite.

16.verse: When David raised his eyes, he saw the angel of the LORD standing between earth and heaven, with a naked sword in his hand stretched out against Jerusalem. David and the elders, clothed in sackcloth, prostrated themselves face to the ground,

17.verse: and David prayed to God: "Was it not I who ordered the census of the people? I am the one who sinned, I did this wicked thing. But these sheep, what have they done? O LORD, my God, strike me and my father's family, but do not afflict your people with this plague!"

18.verse: Then the angel of the LORD commanded Gad to tell David to go up and erect an altar to the LORD on the threshing floor of Ornan the Jebusite.

19.verse: David went up at Gad's command, given in the name of the LORD.

20.verse: While Ornan was threshing wheat, he turned around and saw the king, and his four sons who were with him, without recognizing them.

21.verse: But as David came on toward him, he looked up and saw that it was David. Then he left the threshing floor and bowed down before David, his face to the ground.

22.verse: David said to Ornan: "Sell me the ground of this threshing floor, that I may build on it an altar to the LORD. Sell it to me at its full price, that the plague may be stayed from the people."

23.verse: But Ornan said to David: "Take it as your own, and let my lord the king do what seems best to him. See, I also give you the oxen for the holocausts, the threshing sledges for the wood, and the wheat for the cereal offering. I give it all to you."

24.verse: But King David replied to Ornan: "No! I will buy it from you properly, at its full price. I will not take what is yours for the LORD, nor offer up holocausts that cost me nothing."

25.verse: So David paid Ornan six hundred shekels of gold for the place.

26.verse: David then built an altar there to the LORD, and offered up holocausts and peace offerings. When he called upon the LORD, he answered him by sending down fire from heaven upon the altar of holocausts.

27.verse: Then the LORD gave orders to the angel to return his sword to its sheath.

28.verse: Once David saw that the LORD had heard him on the threshing floor of Ornan the Jebusite, he continued to offer sacrifices there.

29.verse: The Dwelling of the LORD, which Moses had built in the desert, and the altar of holocausts were at that time on the high place at Gibeon.

30.verse: But David could not go there to worship God, for he was fearful of the sword of the angel of the LORD.

annotations.1: [1] A satan: in the parallel passage of 2 Sam 24:1 the Lord's anger. The change in the term reflects the changed theological outlook of postexilic Israel, when evil could no longer be attributed directly to God. At an earlier period the Hebrew word satan ("adversary," or, especially in a court of law, "accuser"), when not used of men, designated an angel who accused men before God ( Job 1:6-12; 2:1-7; Zechariah 3:1-2). Here, as in later Judaism ( Wisdom 2:24) and in the New Testament, satan, or the "devil" (from the Greek translation of the word), designates an evil spirit who tempts men to wrongdoing.
annotations.2: [25] Six hundred shekels of gold: about 10, 000 dollars. According to 2 Sam 24:24, David paid 50 shekels of silver, about 20 dollars, for Ornan's threshing floor; but for the Chronicler the site of the temple was much more precious than that

1.verse: Afterward Nahash, king of the Ammonites, died and his son succeeded him as king.

2.verse: David said, "I will show kindness to Hanun, the son of Nahash, for his father treated me with kindness." Therefore he sent envoys to him to comfort him over the death of his father. But when David's servants had entered the land of the Ammonites to comfort Hanun,

3.verse: the Ammonite princes said to Hanun, "Do you think David is doing this - sending you these consolers - to honor your father? Have not his servants rather come to you to explore the land, spying it out for its overthrow?"

4.verse: Thereupon Hanun seized David's servants and had them shaved and their garments cut off half-way at the hips. Then he sent them away.

5.verse: When David was informed of what had happened to his men, he sent messengers to meet them, for the men had been greatly disgraced. "Remain at Jericho," the king told them, "until your beards have grown again; and then you may come back here."

6.verse: When the Ammonites realized that they had put themselves in bad odor with David, Hanun and the Ammonites sent a thousand talents of silver to hire chariots and horsemen from Aram Naharaim, from Aram-maacah, and from Zobah.

7.verse: They hired thirty-two thousand chariots along with the king of Maacah and his army, who came and encamped before Medeba. The Ammonites also assembled from their cities and came out for war.

8.verse: When David heard of this, he sent Joab and his whole army of warriors against them.

9.verse: The Ammonites marched out and lined up for a battle at the gate of the city, while the kings who had come to their help remained apart in the open field.

10.verse: When Joab saw that there was a battle line both in front of and behind him, he chose some of the best fighters among the Israelites and set them in array against the Arameans;

11.verse: the rest of the army, which he placed under the command of his brother Abishai, then lined up to oppose the Ammonites.

12.verse: And he said: "If the Arameans prove too strong for me, you must come to my help; and if the Ammonites prove too strong for you, I will save you.

13.verse: Hold steadfast and let us show ourselves courageous for the sake of our people and the cities of our God; then may the LORD do what seems best to him."

14.verse: Joab therefore advanced with his men to engage the Arameans in battle; but they fled before him.

15.verse: And when the Ammonites saw that the Arameans had fled, they also took to flight before his brother Abishai, and reentered the city. Joab then returned to Jerusalem.

16.verse: Seeing themselves vanquished by Israel, the Arameans sent messengers to bring out the Arameans from the other side of the River, with Shophach, the general of Hadadezer's army, at their head.

17.verse: When this was reported to David, he gathered all Israel together, crossed the Jordan, and met them. With the army of David drawn up to fight the Arameans, they gave battle.

18.verse: But the Arameans fled before Israel, and David slew seven thousand of their chariot fighters and forty thousand of their foot soldiers; he also killed Shophach, the general of the army.

19.verse: When the vassals of Hadadezer saw themselves vanquished by Israel, they made peace with David and became his subjects. After this, the Arameans refused to come to the aid of the Ammonites.

1.verse: These were the sons of Israel: Reuben, Simeon, Levi, Judah, Issachar, Zebulun,

2.verse: Dan, Joseph, Benjamin, Naphtali, Gad, and Asher.

3.verse: The sons of Judah were: Er, Onan, and Shelah; these three were born to him of Bathshua, a Canaanite woman. But Judah's first-born, Er, was wicked in the sight of the LORD, so he killed him.

4.verse: Judah's daughter-in-law Tamar bore him Perez and Zerah, so that he had five sons in all.

5.verse: The sons of Perez were Hezron and Hamul.

6.verse: The sons of Zerah were Zimri, Ethan, Heman, Calcol, and Darda - five in all.

7.verse: The sons of Zimri: Carmi. The sons of Carmi: Achar, who brought trouble upon Israel by violating the ban.

8.verse: The sons of Ethan: Azariah.

9.verse: The sons born to Hezron were Jerahmeel, Ram, and Chelubai.

10.verse: Ram became the father of Amminadab, and Amminadab became the father of Nahshon, a prince of the Judahites.

11.verse: Nahshon became the father of Salmah. Salmah became the father of Boaz.

12.verse: Boaz became the father of Obed. Obed became the father of Jesse.

13.verse: Jesse became the father of Eliab, his first-born, of Abinadab, the second son, Shimea, the third,

14.verse: Nethanel, the fourth, Raddai, the fifth,

15.verse: Ozem, the sixth, and David, the seventh.

16.verse: Their sisters were Zeruiah and Abigail. Zeruiah had three sons: Abishai, Joab, and Asahel.

17.verse: Abigail bore Amasa, whose father was Jether the Ishmaelite.

18.verse: By his wife Azubah, Caleb, son of Hezron, became the father of a daughter, Jerioth. Her sons were Jesher, Shobab, and Ardon.

19.verse: When Azubah died, Caleb married Ephrath, who bore him Hur.

20.verse: Hur became the father of Uri, and Uri became the father of Bezalel.

21.verse: Then Hezron had relations with the daughter of Machir, the father of Gilead, having married her when he was sixty years old. She bore him Segub.

22.verse: Segub became the father of Jair, who possessed twenty-three cities in the land of Gilead.

23.verse: Geshur and Aram took from them the villages of Jair, that is, Kenath and its towns, sixty cities in all, which had belonged to the sons of Machir, the father of Gilead.

24.verse: After the death of Hezron, Caleb had relations with Ephrathah, the widow of his father Hezron, and she bore him Ashhur, the father of Tekoa.

25.verse: The sons of Jerahmeel, the first-born of Hezron, were Ram, the first-born, then Bunah, Oren, and Ozem, his brothers.

26.verse: Jerahmeel also had another wife, Atarah by name, who was the mother of Onam.

27.verse: The sons of Ram, the first-born of Jerahmeel, were Maaz, Jamin, and Eker.

28.verse: The sons of Onam were Shammai and Jada. The sons of Shammai were Nadab and Abishur.

29.verse: Abishur's wife, who was named Abihail, bore him Ahban and Molid.

30.verse: The sons of Nadab were Seled and Appaim. Seled died without sons.

31.verse: The sons of Appaim: Ishi. The sons of Ishi: Sheshan. The sons of Sheshan: Ahlai.

32.verse: The sons of Jada, the brother of Shammai, were Jether and Jonathan. Jether died without sons.

33.verse: The sons of Jonathan were Peleth and Zaza. These were the descendants of Jerahmeel.

34.verse: Sheshan, who had no sons, only daughters, had an Egyptian slave named Jarha.

35.verse: Sheshan gave his daughter in marriage to his slave Jarha, and she bore him Attai.

36.verse: Attai became the father of Nathan. Nathan became the father of Zabad.

37.verse: Zabad became the father of Ephlal. Ephlal became the father of Obed.

38.verse: Obed became the father of Jehu. Jehu became the father of Azariah.

39.verse: Azariah became the father of Helez. Helez became the father of Eleasah.

40.verse: Eleasah became the father of Sismai. Sismai became the father of Shallum.

41.verse: Shallum became the father of Jekamiah. Jekamiah became the father of Elishama.

42.verse: The descendants of Caleb, the brother of Jerahmeel: (Mesha) his first-born, who was the father of Ziph. Then the sons of Mareshah, who was the father of Hebron.

43.verse: The sons of Hebron were Korah, Tappuah, Rekem, and Shema.

44.verse: Shema became the father of Raham, who was the father of Jorkeam. Rekem became the father of Shammai.

45.verse: The son of Shammai: Maon, who was the father of Beth-zur.

46.verse: Ephah, Caleb's concubine, bore Haran, Moza, and Gazez. Haran became the father of Gazez.

47.verse: The sons of Jahdai were Regem, Jotham, Geshan, Pelet, Ephah, and Shaaph.

48.verse: Maacah, Caleb's concubine, bore Sheber and Tirhanah.

49.verse: She also bore Shaaph, the father of Madmannah, Sheva, the father of Machbenah, and the father of Gibea. Achsah was Caleb's daughter.

50.verse: These were descendants of Caleb, sons of Hur, the first-born of Ephrathah: Shobal, the father of Kiriath-jearim,

51.verse: Salma, the father of Bethlehem, and Hareph, the father of Bethgader.

52.verse: The sons of Shobal, the father of Kiriath-jearim, were Reaiah, half the Manahathites,

53.verse: and the clans of Kiriath-jearim: the Ithrites, the Puthites, the Shumathites, and the Mishraites. From these the people of Zorah and the Eshtaolites derived.

54.verse: The descendants of Salma were Bethlehem, the Netophathites, Atroth-beth-Joab, half the Manahathites, and the Zorites.

55.verse: The clans of the Sopherim dwelling in Jabez were the Tirathites, the Shimeathites, and the Sucathites. They were the Kenites, who came from Hammath of the ancestor of the Rechabites.

annotations.1: [ 2:3- 4:23] For two reasons, the Chronicler places the genealogy of the tribe of Judah before that of the other tribes, giving it also at greater length than the others: because of his interest in David and because in the Chronicler's time the people of God were almost exclusively Jews. Both David and the Jews were of the tribe of Judah.
annotations.2: [9] Chelubai: a variant form of the name Caleb ( 1 Chron 2:18, 42) distinct from Chelub of 1 Chron 4:11
annotations.3: [10-17] Immediate ancestors of David. A similar list is given in Ruth 4:19-22; each list, independent of the other, derives from a common source
annotations.4: [18-24] Descendants of Caleb. In 1 Chron 4:15 as is often the case in the Pentateuch ( Numbers 13:6; 14:6, 30; 26:65; etc.), Caleb is called son of Jephunneh. Here he is called son of Hezron, perhaps because the Calebites were reckoned as part of the clan of the Hezronites
annotations.5: [25-41] The Jerahmeelites were a clan in the Negeb of Judah
annotations.6: [42-49] Another list, dating from preexilic times, of the Calebites, a clan that inhabited the south of Judah
annotations.7: [50-55] The Hurites, a clan dwelling to the south and west of Jerusalem and related to the Calebites

1.verse: The descendants of Aaron also were divided into classes. The sons of Aaron were Nadab, Abihu, Eleazar, and Ithamar.

2.verse: Nadab and Abihu died before their father, leaving no sons; therefore only Eleazar and Ithamar served as priests.

3.verse: David, with Zadok, a descendant of Eleazar, and Ahimelech, a descendant of Ithamar, assigned the functions for the priestly service.

4.verse: But since the descendants of Eleazar were found to be more numerous than those of Ithamar, the former were divided into sixteen groups, and the latter into eight groups, each under its family head.

5.verse: Their functions were assigned impartially by lot, for there were officers of the holy place, and officers of the divine presence, descended both from Eleazar and from Ithamar.

6.verse: The scribe Shemaiah, son of Nethanel, a Levite, made a record of it in the presence of the king, and of the leaders, of Zadok the priest, and of Ahimelech, son of Abiathar, and of the heads of the ancestral houses of the priests and of the Levites, listing two successive family groups from Eleazar before each one from Ithamar.

8.verse: the third to Harim, the fourth to Seorim,

9.verse: the fifth to Malchijah, the sixth to Mijamin,

10.verse: the seventh to Hakkoz, the eighth to Abijah,

11.verse: the ninth to Jeshua, the tenth to Shecaniah,

12.verse: the eleventh to Eliashib, the twelfth to Jakim,

13.verse: the thirteenth to Huppah, the fourteenth to Ishbaal,

14.verse: the fifteenth to Bilgah, the sixteenth to Immer,

15.verse: the seventeenth to Hezir, the eighteenth to Happizzez,

16.verse: the nineteenth to Pethahiah, the twentieth to Jehezkel,

17.verse: the twenty-first to Jachin, the twenty-second to Gamul,

18.verse: the twenty-third to Delaiah, the twenty-fourth to Maaziah.

19.verse: This was the appointed order of their service when they functioned in the house of the LORD in keeping with the precepts given them by Aaron, their father, as the LORD, the God of Israel, had commanded him.

21.verse: Isshiah, the chief, of the descendants of Rehabiah;

22.verse: Shelomith of the Izharites, and Jahath of the descendants of Shelomith.

23.verse: The descendants of Hebron were Jeriah, the chief, Amariah, the second, Jahaziel, the third, Jekameam, the fourth.

24.verse: The descendants of Uzziel were Micah; Shamir, of the descendants of Micah;

25.verse: Isshiah, the brother of Micah; and Zechariah, a descendant of Isshiah.

26.verse: The descendants of Merari were Mahli, Mushi, and the descendants of his son Uzziah.

27.verse: The descendants of Merari through his son Uzziah: Shoham, Zaccur, and Ibri.

28.verse: Descendants of Mahli were Eleazar, who had no sons,

29.verse: and Jerahmeel, of the descendants of Kish.

30.verse: The descendants of Mushi were Mahli, Eder, and Jerimoth. These were the descendants of the Levites according to their ancestral houses.

31.verse: They too, in the same manner as their relatives, the descendants of Aaron, cast lots in the presence of King David, Zadok, Ahimelech, and the heads of the priestly and levitical families; the more important family did so in the same way as the less important one.

1.verse: The following men came to David in Ziklag while he was still under banishment from Saul, son of Kish; they, too, were among the warriors who helped him in his battles.

2.verse: They were archers who could use either the right or the left hand, both in slinging stones and in shooting arrows with the bow. They were some of Saul's kinsmen, from Benjamin.

3.verse: Ahiezer was their chief, along with Joash, both sons of Shemaah of Gibeah; also Jeziel and Pelet, sons of Azmaveth; Beracah; Jehu, from Anathoth;

4.verse: Ishmaiah the Gibeonite, a warrior on the level of the Thirty, and in addition to their number;

5.verse: Jeremiah; Jahaziel; Johanan; Jozabad from Gederah;

6.verse: Eluzai; Jerimoth; Bealiah; Shemariah; Shephatiah the Haruphite;

7.verse: Elkanah, Isshiah, Azarel, Joezer, and Ishbaal, who were Korahites;

8.verse: Joelah, finally, and Zebadiah, sons of Jeroham, from Gedor.

9.verse: Some of the Gadites also went over to David when he was at the stronghold in the wilderness. They were valiant warriors, experienced soldiers equipped with shield and spear, who bore themselves like lions, and were as swift as the gazelles on the mountains.

10.verse: Ezer was their chief, Obadiah was second, Eliab third,

11.verse: Mishmannah fourth, Jeremiah fifth,

12.verse: Attai sixth, Eliel seventh,

13.verse: Johanan eighth, Elzabad ninth,

14.verse: Jeremiah tenth, and Machbannai eleventh.

15.verse: These Gadites were army commanders, the lesser placed over hundreds and the greater over thousands.

16.verse: It was they who crossed over the Jordan when it was overflowing both its banks in the first month, and dispersed all who were in the valleys to the east and to the west.

17.verse: Some Benjaminites and Judahites also came to David at the stronghold.

18.verse: David went out to meet them and addressed them in these words: "If you come peacefully, to help me, I am of a mind to have you join me. But if you have come to betray me to my enemies though my hands have done no wrong, may the God of our fathers see and punish you."

19.verse: Then spirit enveloped Amasai, the chief of the Thirty, who spoke: "We are yours, O David, we are with you, O son of Jesse. Peace, peace to you, and peace to him who helps you; your God it is who helps you." So David received them and placed them among the leaders of his troops.

20.verse: Men from Manasseh also deserted to David when he came with the Philistines to battle against Saul. However, he did not help the Philistines, for their lords took counsel and sent him home, saying, "At the cost of our heads he will desert to his master Saul."

21.verse: As he was returning to Ziklag, therefore, these deserted to him from Manasseh: Adnah, Jozabad, Jediael, Michael, Jozabad, Elihu, and Zillethai, chiefs of thousands of Manasseh.

22.verse: They helped David by taking charge of his troops, for they were all warriors and became commanders of his army.

23.verse: And from day to day men kept coming to David's help until there was a vast encampment, like an encampment of angels.

24.verse: This is the muster of the detachments of armed troops that came to David at Hebron to transfer to him Saul's kingdom, as the LORD had ordained.

25.verse: Judahites bearing shields and spears: six thousand eight hundred armed troops.

26.verse: Of the Simeonites, warriors fit for battle: seven thousand one hundred.

27.verse: Of the Levites: four thousand six hundred,

28.verse: along with Jehoiada, leader of the line of Aaron, with another three thousand seven hundred,

29.verse: and Zadok, a young warrior, with twenty-two princes of his father's house.

30.verse: Of the Benjaminites, the brethren of Saul: three thousand - until this time, most of them had held their allegiance to the house of Saul.

31.verse: Of the Ephraimites: twenty thousand eight hundred warriors, men renowned in their ancestral houses.

32.verse: Of the half-tribe of Manasseh: eighteen thousand, designated by name to come and make David king.

33.verse: Of the Issacharites, their chiefs who were endowed with an understanding of the times and who knew what Israel had to do: two hundred chiefs, together with all their brethren under their command.

34.verse: From Zebulun, men fit for military service, set in battle array with every kind of weapon for war: fifty thousand men rallying with a single purpose.

35.verse: From Naphtali: one thousand captains, and with them, armed with shield and lance, thirty-seven thousand men.

36.verse: Of the Danites, set in battle array: twenty-eight thousand six hundred.

37.verse: From Asher, fit for military service and set in battle array: forty thousand.

38.verse: From the other side of the Jordan, of the Reubenites, Gadites, and the half-tribe of Manasseh, men equipped with every kind of weapon of war: one hundred and twenty thousand.

39.verse: All these soldiers, drawn up in battle order, came to Hebron with the resolute intention of making David king over all Israel. The rest of Israel was likewise of one mind to make David king.

40.verse: They remained with David for three days, feasting and drinking, for their brethren had prepared for them.

41.verse: Moreover, their neighbors from as far as Issachar, Zebulun, and Naphtali came bringing food on asses, camels, mules, and oxen - provisions in great quantity of meal, pressed figs, raisins, wine, oil, oxen, and sheep. For there was rejoicing in Israel.

annotations.1: [25-38] The Chronicler fills out the pageantry of joyous occasions in keeping with his much later appreciation of the significance of the event in the history of God's people: the numbers in attendance at David's crowning in Hebron (cf 2 Sam 5:1-3) are recounted in the same spirit of enthusiasm which in 1 Chron 12:23 compares David's band of desert freebooters to a numerous encampment of angels.

1.verse: The sons of Reuben, the first-born of Israel. (He was indeed the first-born, but because he disgraced the couch of his father his birthright was given to the sons of Joseph, son of Israel, so that he is not listed in the family records according to birthright.

2.verse: Judah, in fact, became powerful among his brothers, so that the ruler came from him, though the birthright had been Joseph's.)

3.verse: The sons of Reuben, the first-born of Israel, were Hanoch, Pallu, Hezron, and Carmi.

4.verse: His son was Joel, whose son was Shemaiah, whose son was Gog, whose son was Shimei,

5.verse: whose son was Micah, whose son was Reaiah, whose son was Baal,

6.verse: whose son was Beerah, whom Tiglath-pileser, the king of Assyria, took into exile; he was a prince of the Reubenites.

7.verse: His brothers who belonged to his clans, when they were listed in the family records according to their descendants, were: Jeiel, the chief, and Zechariah,

8.verse: and Bela, son of Azaz, son of Shema, son of Joel. The Reubenites lived in Aroer and as far as Nebo and Baal-meon;

9.verse: toward the east they dwelt as far as the desert which extends from the Euphrates River, for they had much livestock in the land of Gilead.

10.verse: During the reign of Saul they waged war with the Hagrites, and when they had defeated them they occupied their tents throughout the region east of Gilead.

11.verse: The Gadites lived alongside them in the land of Bashan as far as Salecah.

12.verse: Joel was chief, Shapham was second in command, and Janai was judge in Bashan.

13.verse: Their brothers, corresponding to their ancestral houses, were: Michael, Meshullam, Sheba, Jorai, Jacan, Zia, and Eber - seven.

14.verse: These were the sons of Abihail, son of Huri, son of Jaroah, son of Gilead, son of Michael, son of Jeshishai, son of Jahdo, son of Buz.

15.verse: Ahi, son of Abdiel, son of Guni, was the head of their ancestral houses.

16.verse: They dwelt in Gilead, in Bashan and its towns, and in all the pasture lands of Sirion to the borders.

17.verse: All were listed in the family records in the time of Jotham, king of Judah, and of Jeroboam, king of Israel.

18.verse: The Reubenites, Gadites, and half-tribe of Manasseh were warriors, men who bore shield and sword and who drew the bow, trained in warfare - forty-four thousand seven hundred and sixty men fit for military service.

19.verse: When they waged war against the Hagrites and against Jetur, Naphish, and Nodab,

20.verse: they received help so that they mastered the Hagrites and all who were with them. For during the battle they called on God, and he heard them because they had put their trust in him.

21.verse: Along with one hundred thousand men they also captured their livestock: fifty thousand camels, two hundred fifty thousand sheep, and two thousand asses.

22.verse: Many had fallen in battle, for victory is from God; and they took over their dwelling place until the time of the exile.

23.verse: The numerous members of the half-tribe of Manasseh lived in the land of Bashan as far as Baal-hermon, Senir, and Mount Hermon.

24.verse: The following were the heads of their ancestral houses: Epher, Ishi, Eliel, Azriel, Jeremiah, Hodaviah, and Jahdiel - men who were warriors, famous men, and heads over their ancestral houses.

25.verse: However, they offended the God of their fathers by lusting after the gods of the natives of the land, whom God had cleared out of their way.

26.verse: Therefore the God of Israel incited against them the anger of Pul, king of Assyria, and of Tiglath-pileser, king of Assyria, who deported the Reubenites, the Gadites, and the half-tribe of Manasseh and brought them to Halah, Habor, and Hara, and to the river Gozan, where they have remained to this day.

27.verse: The sons of Levi were Gershon, Kohath, and Merari.

28.verse: The sons of Kohath were Amram, Izhar, Hebron, and Uzziel.

29.verse: The children of Amram were Aaron, Moses, and Miriam. The sons of Aaron were Nadab, Abihu, Eleazar, and Ithamar.

30.verse: Eleazar became the father of Phinehas. Phinehas became the father of Abishua.

31.verse: Abishua became the father of Bukki. Bukki became the father of Uzzi.

32.verse: Uzzi became the father of Zerahiah. Zerahiah became the father of Meraioth.

33.verse: Meraioth became the father of Amariah. Amariah became the father of Ahitub.

34.verse: Ahitub became the father of Zadok. Zadok became the father of Ahimaaz.

35.verse: Ahimaaz became the father of Azariah. Azariah became the father of Johanan.

36.verse: Johanan became the father of Azariah, who served as priest in the temple Solomon built in Jerusalem.

37.verse: Azariah became the father of Amariah. Amariah became the father of Ahitub.

38.verse: Ahitub became the father of Zadok. Zadok became the father of Shallum.

39.verse: Shallum became the father of Hilkiah. Hilkiah became the father of Azariah.

40.verse: Azariah became the father of Seraiah. Seraiah became the father of Jehozadak.

41.verse: Jehozadak was one of those who went into the exile which the LORD inflicted on Judah and Jerusalem through Nebuchadnezzar.

annotations.1: [1-26] The Transjordan tribes.
annotations.2: [26] Pul: the name which the Assyrian king Tiglath-pileser III (745-727 B.C.) took as king of Babylon
annotations.3: [ 5:27- 6:66] The tribe of Levi. The list gives special prominence to Levi's son Kohath, from whom were descended both the Aaronite priests ( 1 Chron 5:26[26-41]) and the leading group of temple singers ( 1 Chron 6:18-23)
annotations.4: [30-41] The line of preexilic priests. The list seems to be confused in 1 Chron 5:26(36-38), which repeat the names, mostly in inverse order, that occur in 1 Chron 5:26(34-36). A similar but shorter list is given, with variations, in Ezra 7:1-5

1.verse: Therefore David said, "This is the house of the LORD God, and this is the altar of holocausts for Israel."

2.verse: David then ordered that all the aliens who lived in the land of Israel be brought together, and he appointed them stonecutters to hew out stone blocks for building the house of God.

3.verse: He also laid up large stores of iron to make nails for the doors of the gates, and clamps, together with so much bronze that it could not be weighed,

4.verse: and cedar trees without number. The Sidonians and Tyrians brought great stores of cedar logs to David,

5.verse: who said: "My son Solomon is young and immature; but the house that is to be built for the LORD must be made so magnificent that it will be renowned and glorious in all countries. Therefore I will make preparations for it." Thus before his death David laid up materials in abundance.

6.verse: Then he called for his son Solomon and commanded him to build a house for the LORD, the God of Israel.

7.verse: David said to Solomon: "My son, it was my purpose to build a house myself for the honor of the LORD, my God.

8.verse: But this word of the LORD came to me: 'You have shed much blood, and you have waged great wars. You may not build a house in my honor, because you have shed too much blood upon the earth in my sight.

9.verse: However, a son is to be born to you. He will be a peaceful man, and I will give him rest from all his enemies on every side. For Solomon shall be his name, and in his time I will bestow peace and tranquillity on Israel.

10.verse: It is he who shall build a house in my honor; he shall be a son to me, and I will be a father to him, and I will establish the throne of his kingship over Israel forever.'

11.verse: Now, my son, the LORD be with you, and may you succeed in building the house of the LORD your God, as he has said you shall.

12.verse: May the LORD give you prudence and discernment when he brings you to rule over Israel, so that you keep the law of the LORD, your God.

13.verse: Only then shall you succeed, if you are careful to observe the precepts and decrees which the LORD gave Moses for Israel. Be brave and steadfast; do not fear or lose heart.

14.verse: See, with great effort I have laid up for the house of the LORD a hundred thousand talents of gold, a million talents of silver, and bronze and iron in such great quantities that they cannot be weighed. I have also stored up wood and stones, to which you must add.

15.verse: Moreover, you have available an unlimited supply of workmen, stonecutters, masons, carpenters, and every kind of craftsman

16.verse: skilled in gold, silver, bronze, and iron. Set to work, therefore, and the LORD be with you!"

17.verse: David also commanded all of Israel's leaders to help his son Solomon:

18.verse: "Is not the LORD your God with you? Has he not given you rest on every side? Indeed, he has delivered the occupants of the land into my power, and the land is subdued before the LORD and his people.

19.verse: Therefore, devote your hearts and souls to seeking the LORD your God. Proceed to build the sanctuary of the LORD God, that the ark of the covenant of the LORD and God's sacred vessels may be brought into the house built in honor of the LORD."

annotations.1: [2-4] According to 1 Kings 5:15-18,(15-32) it was Solomon who made the material preparations for building the temple, even though David had wished to do so ( 1 Kings 5:17-18[17-29]). The Chronicler, however, sought to have David, who was Israel's ideal king, more closely connected with Israel's most sacred sanctuary, the temple of Jerusalem.
annotations.2: [9] The Hebrew word for peace, shalom, is reflected in the name Solomon, in Hebrew, Shelomo. A contrast is drawn here between Solomon, the peaceful man, and David, who waged great wars ( 1 Chron 22:8). David was prevented from building the temple, not only because all his time was taken up in waging war ( 1 Kings 5:17), but also, because he shed much blood ( 1 Chron 22:8), and in the eyes of the Chronicler this made him ritually unfit for the task
annotations.3: [14] A hundred thousand talents of gold: about 3,775 tons of gold. A million talents of silver: about 37,750 tons of silver. The fantastically exaggerated figures are intended merely to stress the inestimable value of the temple as the center of Israelite worship. More modest figures are given in 1 Kings 9:14, 28; 10:10, 14

1.verse: This is the list of the Israelite family heads, commanders of thousands and of hundreds, and other officers who served the king in all that pertained to the divisions, of twenty-four thousand men each, that came and went month by month throughout the year.

2.verse: Over the first division for the first month was Ishbaal, son of Zabdiel, and in his division were twenty-four thousand men;

3.verse: a descendant of Perez, he was chief over all the commanders of the army for the first month.

4.verse: Over the division of the second month was Eleazar, son of Dodo, from Ahoh, and in his division were twenty-four thousand men.

5.verse: The third army commander, chief for the third month, was Benaiah, son of Jehoiada the priest, and in his division were twenty-four thousand men.

6.verse: This Benaiah was a warrior among the Thirty and over the Thirty. His son Ammizabad was over his division.

7.verse: Fourth, for the fourth month, was Asahel, brother of Joab, and after him his son Zebadiah, and in his division were twenty-four thousand men.

8.verse: Fifth, for the fifth month, was the commander Shamhuth, a descendant of Zerah, and in his division were twenty-four thousand men.

9.verse: Sixth, for the sixth month, was Ira, son of Ikkesh, from Tekoa, and in his division were twenty-four thousand men.

10.verse: Seventh, for the seventh month, was Hellez, from Beth-phelet, of the sons of Ephraim, and in his division were twenty-four thousand men.

11.verse: Eighth, for the eighth month, was Sibbecai the Hushathite, a descendant of Zerah, and in his division were twenty-four thousand men.

12.verse: Ninth, for the ninth month, was Abiezer from Anathoth, of Benjamin, and in his division were twenty-four thousand men.

13.verse: Tenth, for the tenth month, was Maharai from Netophah, a descendant of Zerah, and in his division were twenty-four thousand men.

14.verse: Eleventh, for the eleventh month, was Benaiah the Pirathonite, of Ephraim, and in his division were twenty-four thousand men.

15.verse: Twelfth, for the twelfth month, was Heldai the Netophathite, of the family of Othniel, and in his division were twenty-four thousand men.

16.verse: Over the tribes of Israel, for the Reubenites the leader was Eliezer, son of Zichri; for the Simeonites, Shephatiah, son of Maacah;

17.verse: for Levi, Hashabiah, son of Kemuel; for Aaron, Zadok;

18.verse: for Judah, Eliab, one of David's brothers; for Issachar, Omri, son of Michael;

19.verse: for Zebulun, Ishmaiah, son of Obadiah; for Naphtali, Jeremoth, son of Azriel;

20.verse: for the sons of Ephraim, Hoshea, son of Azaziah; for the half-tribe of Manasseh, Joel, son of Pedaiah;

21.verse: for the half-tribe of Manasseh in Gilead, Iddo, son of Zechariah; for Benjamin, Jaasiel, son of Abner;

22.verse: for Dan, Azarel, son of Jeroham. These were the commanders of the tribes of Israel.

23.verse: David did not count those who were twenty years of age or younger, for the LORD had promised to multiply Israel like the stars of the heavens.

24.verse: Joab, son of Zeruiah, began to take the census, but he did not complete it, for because of it wrath fell upon Israel. Therefore the number did not enter into the book of chronicles of King David.

25.verse: Over the treasures of the king was Azmaveth, the son of Adiel. Over the stores in the country, the cities, the villages, and the towers was Jonathan, son of Uzziah.

26.verse: Over the farm workers who tilled the soil was Ezri, son of Chelub.

27.verse: Over the vineyards was Shimei from Ramah, and over their produce for the wine cellars was Zabdi the Shiphmite.

28.verse: Over the olive trees and sycamores of the foothills was Baalhanan the Gederite, and over the stores of oil was Joash.

29.verse: Over the cattle that grazed in Sharon was Shitrai the Sharonite, and over the cattle in the valleys was Shaphat, the son of Adlai;

30.verse: over the camels was Obil the Ishmaelite; over the she-asses was Jehdeiah the Meronothite;

31.verse: and over the flocks was Jaziz the Hagrite. All these were the overseers of King David's possessions.

32.verse: Jonathan, David's uncle and a man of intelligence, was counselor and scribe; he and Jehiel, the son of Hachmoni, were tutors of the king's sons.

33.verse: Ahithophel was also the king's counselor, and Hushai the Archite was the king's confidant.

34.verse: After Ahithophel came Jehoiada, the son of Benaiah, and Abiathar. The commander of the king's army was Joab.

annotations.1: [1-15] This list of army commanders is similar to, but distinct from, the list of David's warriors as given in 1 Chron 11:10-47. The schematic enumeration of the soldiers as presented here is, no doubt, artificial and grossly exaggerated (12 x 24,000 = 288,000 men!), unless the Hebrew word (eleph) for thousand is understood as designating a military unit of much smaller size; see note on 1 Chron 12:25-38.
annotations.2: [34] After Ahithophel: after his suicide ( 2 Sam 17:23). Jehoiada then succeeded him as the king's counselor. Abiathar: the priest. The Chronicler does not mention his office because he regards only the Zadokites as legitimate high priests

1.verse: They brought in the ark of God and set it within the tent which David had pitched for it. Then they offered up holocausts and peace offerings to God.

2.verse: When David had finished offering up the holocausts and peace offerings, he blessed the people in the name of the LORD,

3.verse: and distributed to every Israelite, to every man and every woman, a loaf of bread, a piece of meat, and a raisin cake.

4.verse: He now appointed certain Levites to minister before the ark of the LORD, to celebrate, thank, and praise the LORD, the God of Israel.

5.verse: Asaph was their chief, and second to him were Zechariah, Uzziel, Shemiramoth, Jehiel, Mattithiah, Eliab, Benaiah, Obed-edom, and Jeiel. These were to play on harps and lyres, while Asaph was to sound the cymbals,

6.verse: and the priests Benaiah and Jahaziel were to be the regular trumpeters before the ark of the covenant of God.

7.verse: Then, on that same day, David appointed Asaph and his brethren to sing for the first time these praises of the LORD:

8.verse: Give thanks to the LORD, invoke his name; make known among the nations his deeds.

9.verse: Sing to him, sing his praise, proclaim all his wondrous deeds.

10.verse: Glory in his holy name; rejoice, O hearts that seek the LORD!

11.verse: Look to the LORD in his strength; seek to serve him constantly.

12.verse: Recall the wondrous deeds that he has wrought, his portents, and the judgments he has uttered,

13.verse: You descendants of Israel, his servants, sons of Jacob, his chosen ones!

14.verse: He, the LORD, is our God; throughout the earth his judgments prevail.

15.verse: He remembers forever his covenant which he made binding for a thousand generations -

16.verse: Which he entered into with Abraham and by his oath to Isaac;

17.verse: Which he established for Jacob by statute, for Israel as an everlasting covenant,

18.verse: Saying, "To you will I give the land of Canaan as your allotted inheritance."

19.verse: When they were few in number, a handful, and strangers there,

20.verse: Wandering from nation to nation, from one kingdom to another people,

21.verse: He let no one oppress them, and for their sake he rebuked kings:

22.verse: "Touch not my anointed, and to my prophets do no harm."

23.verse: Sing to the LORD, all the earth, announce his salvation, day after day

24.verse: Tell his glory among the nations; among all peoples, his wondrous deeds.

25.verse: For great is the LORD and highly to be praised; and awesome is he, beyond all gods.

26.verse: For all the gods of the nations are things of nought, but the LORD made the heavens.

27.verse: Splendor and majesty go before him; praise and joy are in his holy place.

28.verse: Give to the LORD, you families of nations, give to the LORD glory and praise;

29.verse: Give to the LORD the glory due his name! Bring gifts, and enter his presence; worship the LORD in holy attire.

30.verse: Tremble before him, all the earth; he has made the world firm, not to be moved.

31.verse: Let the heavens be glad and the earth rejoice; let them say among the nations: The LORD is king.

32.verse: Let the sea and what fills it resound; let the plains rejoice and all that is in them!

33.verse: Then shall all the trees of the forest exult before the LORD, for he comes: he comes to rule the earth.

34.verse: Give thanks to the LORD, for he is good, for his kindness endures forever;

35.verse: And say, "Save us, O God, our savior, gather us and deliver us from the nations, That we may give thanks to your holy name and glory in praising you."

36.verse: Blessed be the LORD, the God of Israel, through all eternity! Let all the people say, Amen! Alleluia.

37.verse: Then David left Asaph and his brethren there before the ark of the covenant of the LORD to minister before the ark regularly according to the daily ritual;

38.verse: he also left there Obed-edom and sixty-eight of his brethren, including Obed-edom, son of Jeduthun, and Hosah, to be gatekeepers.

39.verse: But the priest Zadok and his priestly brethren he left before the Dwelling of the LORD on the high place at Gibeon,

40.verse: to offer holocausts to the LORD on the altar of holocausts regularly, morning and evening, and to do all that is written in the law of the LORD which he has decreed for Israel.

41.verse: With them were Heman and Jeduthun and the others who were chosen and designated by name to give thanks to the LORD, "because his kindness endures forever,"

42.verse: with trumpets and cymbals for accompaniment, and instruments for the sacred chant. The sons of Jeduthun kept the gate.

43.verse: Then all the people departed, each to his own home, and David returned to bless his household.

annotations.1: [8-36] A hymn composed of parts, with textual variants, from several Psalms: 1 Chron 16:8-22 = Psalm 105:1-15; 1 Chron 16:23-33 = Psalm 96:1-13; 1 Chron 16:34-36 = Psalm 106:1, 47-48.

1.verse: David built houses for himself in the City of David and prepared a place for the ark of God, pitching a tent for it there.

2.verse: At that time he said, "No one may carry the ark of God except the Levites, for the LORD chose them to carry the ark of the LORD and to minister to him forever."

3.verse: Then David assembled all Israel in Jerusalem to bring the ark of the LORD to the place which he had prepared for it.

4.verse: David also called together the sons of Aaron and the Levites:

5.verse: of the sons of Kohath, Uriel, their chief, and one hundred and twenty of his brethren;

6.verse: of the sons of Merari, Asaiah, their chief, and two hundred and twenty of his brethren;

7.verse: of the sons of Gershon, Joel, their chief, and one hundred and thirty of his brethren;

8.verse: of the sons of Elizaphan, Shemaiah, their chief, and two hundred of his brethren;

9.verse: of the sons of Hebron, Eliel, their chief, and eighty of his brethren;

10.verse: of the sons of Uzziel, Amminadab, their chief, and one hundred and twelve of his brethren.

11.verse: David summoned the priests Zadok and Abiathar, and the Levites Uriel, Asaiah, Joel, Shemaiah, Eliel, and Amminadab,

12.verse: and said to them: "You, the heads of the levitical families, must sanctify yourselves along with your brethren and bring the ark of the LORD, the God of Israel, to the place which I have prepared for it.

13.verse: Because you were not with us the first time, the wrath of the LORD our God burst upon us, for we did not seek him aright."

14.verse: Accordingly, the priests and the Levites sanctified themselves to bring up the ark of the LORD, the God of Israel.

15.verse: The Levites bore the ark of God on their shoulders with poles, as Moses had ordained according to the word of the LORD.

16.verse: David commanded the chiefs of the Levites to appoint their brethren as chanters, to play on musical instruments, harps, lyres, and cymbals, to make a loud sound of rejoicing.

17.verse: Therefore the Levites appointed Heman, son of Joel, and, among his brethren, Asaph, son of Berechiah; and among the sons of Merari, their brethren, Ethan, son of Kushaiah;

18.verse: and, together with these, their brethren of the second rank: the gatekeepers Zechariah, Uzziel, Shemiramoth, Jehiel, Unni, Eliab, Benaiah, Maaseiah, Mattithiah, Eliphelehu, Mikneiah, Obed-edom, and Jeiel.

19.verse: The chanters, Heman, Asaph, and Ethan, sounded brass cymbals.

20.verse: Zechariah, Uzziel, Shemiramoth, Jehiel, Unni, Eliab, Maaseiah, and Benaiah played on harps set to "Alamoth."

21.verse: But Mattithiah, Eliphelehu, Mikneiah, Obed-edom, and Jeiel led the chant on lyres set to "the eighth."

22.verse: Chenaniah was the chief of the Levites in the chanting; he directed the chanting, for he was skillful.

verses.1:
1 Chronicles
Introduction
Originally the two books of Chronicles formed, with the Books of Ezra and Nehemiah, a single historical work, uniform in style and basic ideas. The Greek title, paraleipomena, means "things omitted, or passed over (in Samuel and Kings)." The Books of Chronicles, however, are more than a supplement to Samuel and Kings; a comparison of the two histories discloses striking differences in scope and purpose. The Books of Chronicles record in some detail the lengthy span from the reign of Saul to the return from the Exile. Unlike the exact science of history today, wherein factual accuracy and impartiality of judgment are the standards for estimating what is of permanent worth, ancient biblical history, with rare exceptions, was less concerned with reporting in precise detail all the facts of a situation than with explaining the meaning of those facts. Such history was primarily interpretative and, in the Old Testament, its purpose was to disclose the action of the living God in the affairs of men. For this reason we speak of it as "sacred history"; its writer's first concern was to bring out the divine or supernatural dimension in history
This is apparent when we examine the primary objective of the Chronicler in compiling his work. In view of the situation which confronted the Jewish people at this time (the end of the fifth century B.C.), the Chronicler realized that Israel's political greatness was a thing of the past. It would be a people under God, or nothing. Yet Israel's past held the key to her future. The Chronicler proposed to establish and defend the legitimate claims of the Davidic monarchy in Israel's history, and to underscore the place of Jerusalem and its divinely established temple worship as the center of religious life for the Jewish community of his day. If Judaism was to survive and prosper, it would have to heed the lessons of the past and devoutly serve Yahweh in the place where he had chosen to dwell, the temple of Jerusalem. From the Chronicler's point of view, David's reign was the ideal to which all subsequent rule in Judah must aspire
The Chronicler was much more interested in David's religious and cultic influence than in his political power. There is little of royal messianism in his book. He apparently regarded as something of the distant past the prophet Zechariah's abortive attempt to have the Davidic kingdom reestablished in the time of Zerubbabel at the end of the sixth century B.C. ( Zechariah 6:9-15). He saw David's primary importance as deriving from the establishment of Jerusalem and its temple as the center of the true worship of the Lord. Furthermore, he presented David as the one who had authorized the elaborate ritual (which, in point of fact, only gradually evolved in the temple built by Zerubbabel) and who had also appointed Levites to supervise the liturgical services there
There are good reasons for believing that originally the Books of Ezra and Nehemiah formed the last part of a single literary work that began with 1 and 2 Chronicles. Some authors even regard Ezra himself as having been the anonymous Chronicler. In any case, the Chronicler's Hebrew as well as his religious and political outlook points to c. 400 B.C. as the time of composition of this work
The Chronicler used sources in writing his history. Besides the canonical Books of Genesis, Exodus, Numbers, Joshua and Ruth, and especially the Books of Samuel and Kings, he cites the titles of many other works no longer extant. "The books of the kings of Israel," or "the books of the kings of Israel and Judah," "the history of Samuel the seer," "the history of Nathan the prophet," "the history of Gad the seer," "the commentary on the Books of Kings," are some of the documents mentioned as historical sources
In addition, the Chronicler's work contains early preexilic material not found in the Books of Kings. At one time scholars discounted the value of this material, but modern research has shown that, even though the Chronicler may have at times treated the material rather freely, he derived it from authentic and reliable sources
The principal divisions of 1 Chronicles are as follows
I. Genealogical Tables ( 1 Chron 1:1- 9:34)
II. The History of David ( 1 Chron 9:35- 29:30)

annotations.1: [ 1:1- 9:34] The Chronicler set as his task the retelling, from his particular viewpoint, of the story of God's people from the beginning to his own day. Since his primary interest was the history of David and the Davidic dynasty of Judah, he presents through mere genealogical lists a summary of what preceded the reign of Saul, David's predecessor in the kingdom. The sources for these genealogies are mostly the canonical Hebrew Scriptures that were already in their present form in his time. The cross references in this book indicate in each case the scriptural sources used.

annotations.1: [13-14] The Chronicler's comment on why Saul met his tragic end: he had disobeyed the Lord's command given through the prophet Samuel ( 1 Sam 15:3-9), and had sought counsel of a necromancer ( 1 Sam 28:6-19), contrary to the Mosaic law against necromancy ( Deut 18:10-11).

1.verse: After David had taken up residence in his house, he said to Nathan the prophet, "See, I am living in a house of cedar, but the ark of the covenant of the LORD dwells under tentcloth."

2.verse: Nathan replied to David, "Do, therefore, whatever you desire, for God is with you."

3.verse: But that same night the word of God came to Nathan:

4.verse: "Go and tell my servant David, Thus says the LORD: It is not you who are to build a house for me to dwell in.

5.verse: For I have never dwelt in a house, from the time when I led Israel onward, even to this day, but I have been lodging in tent or pavilion

6.verse: as long as I have wandered about with all of Israel. Did I ever say a word to any of the judges of Israel whom I commanded to guide my people, such as, 'Why have you not built me a house of cedar?'

7.verse: Therefore, tell my servant David, Thus says the LORD of hosts: I took you from the pasture, from following the sheep, that you might become ruler over my people Israel.

8.verse: I was with you wherever you went, and I cut down all your enemies before you. I will make your name great like that of the greatest on the earth.

9.verse: I will assign a place for my people Israel and I will plant them in it to dwell there henceforth undisturbed; nor shall wicked men ever again oppress them, as they did at first,

10.verse: and during all the time when I appointed judges over my people Israel. And I will subdue all your enemies. Moreover, I declare to you that I, the LORD, will build you a house;

11.verse: so that when your days have been completed and you must join your fathers, I will raise up your offspring after you who will be one of your own sons, and I will establish his kingdom.

12.verse: He it is who shall build me a house, and I will establish his throne forever.

13.verse: I will be a father to him, and he shall be a son to me, and I will not withdraw my favor from him as I withdrew it from him who preceded you;

14.verse: but I will maintain him in my house and in my kingdom forever, and his throne shall be firmly established forever."

15.verse: All these words and this whole vision Nathan related exactly to David.

16.verse: Then David came in and sat in the LORD'S presence, saying: "Who am I, O LORD God, and what is my family, that you should have brought me as far as I have come?

17.verse: And yet, even this you now consider too little, O God! For you have made a promise regarding your servant's family reaching into the distant future, and you have looked on me as henceforth the most notable of men, O LORD God.

18.verse: What more can David say to you? You know your servant.

19.verse: O LORD, for your servant's sake and in keeping with your purpose, you have done this great thing.

20.verse: O LORD, there is no one like you and there is no God but you, just as we have always understood.

21.verse: "Is there, like your people Israel, whom you redeemed from Egypt, another nation on earth whom a god went to redeem as his people? You won for yourself a name for great and awesome deeds by driving out the nations before your people.

22.verse: You made your people Israel your own forever, and you, O LORD, became their God.

23.verse: Therefore, O LORD, may the promise that you have uttered concerning your servant and his house remain firm forever. Bring about what you have promised,

24.verse: that your renown as LORD of hosts, God of Israel, may be great and abide forever, while the house of David, your servant, is established in your presence.

25.verse: "Because you, O my God, have revealed to your servant that you will build him a house, your servant has made bold to pray before you.

26.verse: Since you, O LORD, are truly God and have promised this good thing to your servant,

27.verse: and since you have deigned to bless the house of your servant, so that it will remain forever - since it is you, O LORD, who blessed it, it is blessed forever."

1.verse: After David had taken counsel with his commanders of thousands and of hundreds, that is to say, with every one of his leaders,

2.verse: he said to the whole assembly of Israel: "If it seems good to you, and is so decreed by the LORD our God, let us summon the rest of our brethren from all the districts of Israel, and also the priests and the Levites from their cities with pasture lands, that they may join us;

3.verse: and let us bring the ark of our God here among us, for in the days of Saul we did not visit it."

4.verse: And the whole assembly agreed to do this, for the idea was pleasing to all the people.

5.verse: Then David assembled all Israel, from Shihor of Egypt to Labo of Hamath, to bring the ark of God from Kiriath-jearim.

6.verse: David and all Israel went up to Baalah, that is, to Kiriath-jearim, of Judah, to bring back the ark of God, which was known by the name "LORD enthroned upon the cherubim."

7.verse: They transported the ark of God on a new cart from the house of Abinadab; Uzzah and Ahio were guiding the cart,

8.verse: while David and all Israel danced before God with great enthusiasm, amid songs and music on lyres, harps, tambourines, cymbals, and trumpets.

9.verse: As they reached the threshing floor of Chidon, Uzzah stretched out his hand to steady the ark, for the oxen were upsetting it.

10.verse: Then the LORD became angry with Uzzah and struck him; he died there in God's presence, because he had laid his hand on the ark.

11.verse: David was disturbed because the LORD'S anger had broken out against Uzzah. Therefore that place has been called Perez-uzza even to this day.

12.verse: David was now afraid of God, and he said, "How can I bring the ark of God with me?"

13.verse: Therefore he did not take the ark back with him to the City of David, but he took it instead to the house of Obed-edom the Gittite.

14.verse: The ark of God remained in the house of Obed-edom with his family for three months, and the LORD blessed Obed-edom's household and all that he possessed.
